Those who engage in regular cold water swims often develop cold adaptation.
As a result of cold adaptation, individuals no longer experience the release of epinephrine and adrenaline in response to cold exposure.
The release of succinate, along with shivering and the activation of brown fat thermogenesis, becomes less intense over time.

Increasing shivering can ultimately promote fat loss more effectively.
